Literature Review: The aging process profoundly affects the structure and function of the retina, a critical component of the visual system. This literature review explores the molecular and cellular changes associated with retinal aging, focusing on neurons and non-neuronal cells, and their implications for visual function. The retina, with its well-defined architecture and diverse cell types, serves as an excellent model for studying neural aging. Age-related alterations in the retina not only contribute to visual decline but also offer insights into broader mechanisms of neural aging and degeneration. Research has shown that aging leads to significant structural changes in the retina, including thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer and loss of photoreceptors. These changes are accompanied by functional declines, such as reduced contrast sensitivity and slower visual processing speeds. At the molecular level, aging is associated with increased oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and altered protein homeostasis, which can lead to neuronal damage and death. Synaptic changes, including alterations in synaptic density and plasticity, are also observed in the aging retina, affecting neural circuit function. Non-neuronal cells, such as glial cells and the retinal pigment epithelium, play crucial roles in maintaining retinal homeostasis and are also affected by aging. Glial cells, for example, exhibit changes in morphology and function that can impact neuronal survival and synaptic function. The retinal pigment epithelium, essential for photoreceptor maintenance, shows age-related declines in phagocytic activity and barrier function, contributing to retinal degeneration. Understanding the mechanisms underlying retinal aging is crucial for developing strategies to mitigate age-related visual decline and restore neural function. Recent advances in molecular biology and imaging technologies have provided new tools for studying retinal aging at the cellular and molecular levels. These tools have enabled researchers to identify potential therapeutic targets and to test interventions aimed at preserving or restoring retinal function in aging. In conclusion, the aging retina represents a complex interplay of structural, functional, and molecular changes that affect both neuronal and non-neuronal cells. Further research is needed to fully understand these changes and to develop effective interventions for age-related retinal and neural decline.
